comments.commentBody: Treason?  B---s--- is the nicest word I can apply to that accusation.

There's nothing vague about this band of Trumpublican cheaters and kleptocrats and destroyers. America of, for, and by the superrich.

Health care: Repeal and Replace with WeDontCare ...

Colbert's "Werd" was pretty good on the subject:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Di9R9oA5Qzk

Tom Price seems a particularly bad figurehead for this nastiness. Death panels for the poor already ...

No one should be able to decide that one life is somehow more valuable than another, not even an individual about his own life.

Our society once placed value in improving the lot of those who are "poor" in some way or another, including the poverty of frailty and mental illness.

We also placed value in resilient, in those able to live their lives despite their circumstances, including the circumstances of failing physical and mental health.

People's fear of suffering, not the suffering itself, drives people to assisted suicide, and that is made very clear both by the article and by the comments here. A woman can no longer talk and so her life must end? And we as a society are to affirm her in this?

No one wants to have dementia, but if I should develop it then my life needs to be ended? That those with it should not have "valuable medical resources" wasted on them? That our life is somehow no longer valuable as another life and so we will end it, and as a society we nod in collective agreement? No, that life is worth our concern and care the same as every other life, not shunned as a life to be destroyed.

FIRST do no harm, then we can talk about autonomy. Aim for beneficence and we will achieve justice. Keep autonomy within these other three guiding principles, not as the trump card over them all.

Right to die humanely with assistance from a physician,  should become a universal human right. People who have good reason to end their lives should be able to do so. This is critical to ensure that people don't commit suicides by resorting to blowing themselves apart with guns or by hanging or jumping off a high rise. The world should not be so cruel as to not understand the pain and suffering of another person and to not let that person end their own suffering in a humane manner. Jack Kervokian was a thinker ahead of his time and unless there has been some innovative painless way to end lives for those who are suffering extremely, then the Kevorkian suicide machine should be the accepted device that can be used and special places can be designated to conduct physician supervised and assisted suicide, with a coroner as a witness and a religious representative at their side if the person ending his or her life chooses. There are roughly 40,000 suicides occurring every year and that number will not change, but what can change is that they will die with dignity, compassion and acceptance by family and friends.

I've been watching the Price hearing for some time, about two hours, on a C-Span re-run. All I can see is Democrats doing the usual attack dog postures and the Republicans asking the protective questions. How unusual that they would all take partisan positions. But, just as the Reps embarrassed themselves in the last Benghazi hearing where Clinton last testified, I see the Dems embarrassing themselves here - and in other some other hearings. Sens. Murray, Whitehouse and especially Sanders in particular. I thought Sen. Paul, who I admire b/c he is not afraid of bucking Reps. when he feels it due, had a great rebuttal to Sanders. I wish school children could hear it.

And, as usual w/ Mr. Trump (who I have never supported except to say he deserves a chance and that the opposition has moved beyond hysteria). So far, watching as many hearings as I can, I felt that the nominees have made a good account of themselves. The media versions of their hearings are not very accurate, but basically slanted to accepting the Dem charges, rather than listening to his answers, which are quite moderate and thoughtful.
I don't think you are listening carefully enough.  Read the Times pick above yours.

AACNY You mean get in there and UNDO UNDO UNDO?  Wreck and wreak havoc? And before you accuse me again of not knowing how middle America thinks and feels, I've lived there as an adult in Texas, Kansas, North Carolina, Ohio, Illinois, East and West Coast...so yes...I do know...and have family and friends throughout.  Sure, about half the picks are at least qualified, but there are 6 that will just do damage to their departments and the people who need there services...and Mr. Price is one of them.

The reason we shouldn't give any deference at all to Trump is because of the way he chose to run his campaign: shouting insults at minorities, instigating violence, arbitrary dejection of citizens, the bullying, the lying, the hostility to and assaulting the press, and decrying First Amendment principals. Do I need to keep going?

Trumpublicans, enablers and bullies all, think they can fix all this.

They want to repeal and replace the environment and the planet.

(h/t Bill Mahr)

Dr. K,

Eventually health insurance will be a right of all Americans. One of the best programs we have for health insurance performance is the program called Medicare. It is a good program, I am on it and it is great, I only wish that the insurance coverage included dental, hearing and eye care so even if I were homeless, I could have good teeth, hearing and vision.

So all we really need to do is staff the Medicare program with more people to take care of the expansion of the insurance. It will be a glorious system, no Medicaid, No VA,

By taking the insurance question off the table, we can turn our attention to the healthcare delivery system. It needs work and I think we can create the best health outcomes oriented system in the world. The system is a natural monopoly and market based competition doesn't really fit the requirements of modern society.

Should we fund environmental protection, global disease monitoring and control, food and drug regulation and the biomedical research at universities and the NIH? I think so. Health insurance has been given far too much attention.

In truth,as everyone knows, It really has been mainly a good, steady and reliable means of raising campaign funds and to milk the pharmaceutical amd medical industries for campaign funds. The health insurance issue has been divisive and polarizing and essentially has distracted public attention from more important issues.

Not sure what you know about the VA; but, there is little that is wrong with it. It works far better than commercial healthcare and provides for exotic issues such as radiation poisoning from expended Uranium artillery rounds. The VA should be separate from Medicare which is a combination of Government, private, and commercial insurance. And yes it does not cover dental or vision.

Thank you for reading my comment.

My thoughts are that anything that VA covers should or would be covered by Medicare. I recognize that the VA has its own treatment facilities both here and the and the World. They are valuable to our treatment system. I just want to convince everyone that health insurance should be for everyone and I have totally lost confidence in the market based systems. The Medicare folks are running a very efficient system and their data is invaluable.

How is it "treason" to reveal that our government was spying on its own citizens? Not a shred of evidence has come forth even to suggest that our national security was strengthened by the work that Snowden and his colleagues were engaged in.

Why was Price's broker buying such medical stocks? Did Price never tell him to avoid stocks which could violate the Stock Act, or otherwise present ethical issues? Has Price never heard of index funds?
That's really funny.

Riiiight.  Trump will create jobs by "stimulating the economy" (a vague assertion with no details to back it up) and Price will create better health care for everyone (with no details to back it up).  America, welcome to the con game.
Could anyone be more legalistic, vague, non-committal, and beyond any promise to actually, specifically do what he only implies and claims adoration to.
"Well, we provided access...they just chose not to take it."
Yep. Hillary Clinton.

Isn't it amazing that a sharp-witted fellow like Price, who prides himself on being on top of every detail about the ACA and all its flaws, conveniently claims ignorance about his highly unethical stock purchases that scream out conflict of interest. Price, like the man who nominated him, lives by the creed that greed is good. He will be rammed through as HHS head and look for 30 million defenseless people to be devastated by his pay for play approach to health care.

America will be shocked to see this part of the government actually conducted with total RESPECT of the LAW. We have gotten so accustomed to lawlessness from this failed president and his administrators that lawful activity will take to again.
What is the sad part of these hearings? People who only lecture the camera and then plead for more time so that they can continue to lecture us.
comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene

comments.commentBody: Depends on what they say in the lecture.  I liked Bernie's lectures

"Lofty goals but vague details.."

Yes indeed. Exactly what we got from the Obama administration. And bad outcomes.

Are you sure you aren't projecting?
We need to credit Obama for what Didn't happen on his watch....there were plenty of opportunities for stupid stuff.

Yes, The Times' newfound interest in details -- and the truth -- is refreshing.  Now that there is a republican at the helm, it will no longer just parrot Administration talking points (ex., "20 million newly insured").
my recollection was there were too many detail, and thus congress people did not have time to read it.

Critics of republican plans told me to listen for the language used as a cover for the scam the republicans are planning to work on the American people/healthcare: "access to" and "high risk pools". Price repeated each several times. As Bernie said to him "I have ACCESS to buy a million dollar home, doesn't mean I have the money to pay for it." I had a good laugh at that, but it's no laughing matter.
Sorry, but this man was the picture of a smug, money-grubber who may have gone into medicine to help his fellow citizens but soon decided he liked helping himself more. No shame whatsoever in admitting that he knowingly and personally bought stocks prior to introducing and passing legislation he knew would greatly increase the value of those stocks. America, I think you're losing your mind...it'll be walking out the front door of the White House on Friday.
Rw - you've described the perfect Republican. Price is a shoe-in with his crowd.

The film-flam continues. Is this "The Apprentice- Presidential Edition" ???
Every hearing reveals the ignorance and distain of the supposed subject of the "candidates" expertise. Random people chosen off the street could show more enthusiasm and desire to do the job, rather than assume a "position". So sad.

Trump never expected to win and with a mad dash to fill positions he did not have time to pick the best people for the jobs.  He is picking people he probably never heard of until his advisors whispered something in his ear.  This will be the most unqualified cabinet in modern history.

The GOP has had no problem letting people fall through the cracks, so why do we believe them now? I don't believe this guy for one minute. I have noticed that they are big on talking about "access". Well, everyone has always had access if you had money. Even with a preexisting condition you could get insurance if you paid enough money for it. Access isn't the same as availability. The ACA's didn't go far enough in controlling costs - which is very difficult in the current environment. I have no faith the GOP will come up with what Trump is claiming - great insurance lower cost, for all.
I also feel that we need to demand that people elected to Congress must establish blind trusts - it is clear to me that they use their information and positions in order to enrich themselves - and that goes for both sides of the aisle. To see this guy sit there and claim that all his stock trading was ethical was disgusting. While it may be legal, we should not allow these people to profit from their offices, which is what many of them apparently do.

Price is such a hypocrite. Blue states like Massachusetts, Connecticut, New York and New Jersey have already expanded medicaid program benefiting their constituents. His state of Georgia and the of the red states have no such program thereby restricting to medical access. Take note, he is a surgeon set of mind. He prefers professional fees for his procedure out of patient's pocket than being dictated by a third party payer for his procedure. That is why he lauded Indiana's conservative healthcare policy because it promote "personal responsibility", that is, paying out of your pocket.

Insider trading and not paying employment taxes are non-starters for those that view the commons as something important and worth defending.

For the average Trump supporter, these are scams they want to get in on themselves. These aren't disqualifying things for the GOP - ripping off the public or Uncle Sam is probably expected among a significant set.

Price has said and done zero to dispel the stink of corruption surrounding his genius investments. And so, as with Trump himself and so many of Trump's nominees, Price is starting off so low many are without doubt hoping the only direction for him to go is up. To characterize this complacent attitude in Trump-esque fashion, one word: Wrong!

As Alan Rusbridger so ably explains in a parallel article, Snowden was appalled by the deception he found and took steps to inform us, the American people, what our government was doing. It's quite a dilemma.

https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/18/opinion/snowden-does-not-deserve-the-...

"I have since met Mr. Snowden on three occasions and have found him to be thoughtful, consistent, levelheaded and public-spirited. He regards the American Constitution with extreme reverence. He has accepted his exile as the price of what he, and others, see as principled action. His technical knowledge afforded him insights into how the power between the state and the citizen was being transformed, perhaps irrevocably."

We are stuck so often between a rock and a hard place, with our government doing things that ultimately cause a great deal of harm, and Trump set to make it much much worse (repeal and replace the planet, they will, along with death panels for the poor), that principled action has become almost impossible.

If we are to survive, we are going to have to stop the looting and exploiting that has become the norm. And Christians need to return to the Jesus of the gospels, not this market based exclusionary judgmental stuff that would put him in Gitmo if he were to appear today. Jesus was, after all, a "terr'ist" according to so many today, should they actually have to deal with him as he was.

"He has accepted his exile as the price of what he, and others, see as principled action"

And we, the American people, accept it. Have fun in Russia, Ed.

Snowden should be pardoned for letting us all know what our government was doing - spying on American citizens.

Leonard Peltier should be pardoned because he may not have been guilty of the act with which he was charged. He's very old now and reported to be in frail health. He should be allowed to live out his final days as a free citizen. Native Americans were here first in any case.

I thought the strategy is to repeal it with a future expiration date and then watch it blow up because of the repeal.  Then they can say it blew up, anything we pass is better.  Then they will actually jump through hoops and disguise costs and cut benefits with something similar but less effective than Obamacare.  The most important part will be to see that only Clinton voters wind up with less. Mistakes may be made. It's a tricky feat to pull off but not impossible.  Krugman makes the whole idea of repeal as doomed to failure.  Just like his pronouncement on Trump's campaign.  But Krugman is infallible, it was Putin and Comney who stole the election and not Democratic stupidity and neglect that made it even close.

He is not arguing that philosophy is only fit for european white men. I believe what my professor is arguing is that modern academic philosophy or 'real' philosophy has become entrenched in this western school of thought in which philosophy is only to be debated amongst credited scholars. Hence the notion that one studies philosophy to teach philosophy without any practical applications. This notion is true only of western academic 'real' philosophy a field which has been historically dominated by white men and largely neglects the teachings of oriental thinkers.
